qas.question: The first half of the 20th century was marked by what in Russia and the Soviet Union?

answers.text: succession of wars, famines and other disasters

qas.question: Who estimated the Russian population was 90 million fewer than it could have been in 1945?
When was the Russian population estimated to be about 90 million fewer than it could have been?
What was marked by succession of wars, famines, and other disasters in the 20th century?
When did Stephen J. Lee make his estimate about the Russian population?
How many people did famine kill in Russia?
Who did Russia fight with in the first half of the 20th century?
What is Stephen J. Lee's nationality?

context: The first half of the 20th century in <a3_0>Russia and <b6_0>the Soviet Union<b6_0/><a3_0/> was marked by a <a0_0>succession of wars, famines and other disasters<a0_0/>, each accompanied by large-scale population losses. <a1_0><b7_0>Stephen J. Lee<b7_0/><a1_0/> estimates that, by the end of World War II in <a2_0><b4_0>1945<b4_0/><a2_0/>, the <b8_0>Russian<b8_0/> population was about <b5_0>90 million<b5_0/> fewer than it could have been otherwise.
